prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: The Panel does not have any fixed limitations on when it can order transfer. The Panel normally enters a conditional transfer order as soon as it learns of a potential tag-along action, but this can occur at any time during the pendency of the tag-along action and at any time during the pendency of the actions previously transferred. In practice, the Panel will be unlikely to transfer a recently filed tag-along action if the previously transferred actions are on the verge of remand. The Panel will typically transfer tag-along actions without regard to the pendency of motions. Occasionally, however, the Panel may defer a decision until a motion pending in the transferor court can be decided.[1]

The Panel has transferred actions even after the settlement of the previously transferred litigation.[2] Perhaps the ultimate tag-along action existed in the Grain Shipments litigation. In that group of cases the Panel ordered transfer of a group of cases as tag-along actions despite the fact that all pretrial proceedings in the cases previously transferred had been completed.[3] The Panel ordered the cases transferred as tag-along cases for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in a different district than the previously transferred cases.[4] In one case, the Panel ordered remand of a large number of actions at the transferee court's suggestion and granted motions to vacate conditional transfer orders relating to six potential tag-along actions.[5] At the suggestion of the trial court, the Panel then ordered remand of 83 actions that had “opted out” of a consolidated trial held in the remaining transferred cases. Because that trial resulted in a verdict of no liability on the part of the defendant, proceedings in the transferee court had essentially ended.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
State of Illinois v. AU Optronics Corp. (In re TFT-LCD (Flat Panel) Antitrust Litigation) 764 F. Supp. 2d 1338 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (noting postponement is contrary to Panel's usual practice).
See In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 355 F. Supp. 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
In re Commodity Credit Corp. Litigation Involving Grain Shipments (No. 11), 364 F. Supp. 462, 463 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
In re Commodity Credit Corp. Litigation Involving Grain Shipments (No. 11), 364 F. Supp. 462, 463 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
